10904Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USBostons10904-012-9688-6968810.1007/s10904-012-9688-6ArticleTwo Lanthanide-Based Metal–Organic Frameworks with Flexible Alicyclic Carboxylate Ligands: Synthesis, Crystal Structures, and Near-Infrared Luminescence PropertyZhuXian-Dong1aHangZhi-Xi1ZhaoJun2HeJin-Run2WangYu-Ling2grid.461986.40000000417607968College of Biological and Chemical EngineeringAnhui Polytechnic University241000WuhuPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.418036.80000000417933165State Key Laboratory of Structural ChemistryFujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences350002FuzhouPeople’s Republic of Chinazhuxd@ahpu.edu.cn9520129201222510871092264201210320122642012952012© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20122012Abstract

Two lanthanide-based metal–organic frameworks with flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands, generally formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), have been successfully synthesized and characterized. They represent the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from 1D infinite chains to 2D extended layer structure. Complexes 2 exhibit strong fluorescent emissions in the near-infrared region at room temperature. Interestingly, the structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligands and dimension of LMOFs.

The current interest in the crystal engineering of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) stems not only from their potential application as functional materials, but also from their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies [1–4]. In order to design and synthesize novel MOFs with specific structures and properties, much effort has been focused on choosing the favored geometry and function of metal ions and organic ligands. Trivalent lanthanide ions, showing a wide range of technological applications, such as diagnostic tools, luminescent sensors and laser systems, has become important choice of functional metal ions in designing novel MOFs [5–8]. Besides, lanthanide-based MOFs (LMOFs) are expected to have intriguing structural features and charming topologies, owing to their higher coordination number and variable coordination geometry than transitional metals [9–11]. It is well-known that aromatic carboxylate ligands are excellent candidates to construct LMOFs with well-defined secondary building units and versatile architectures, and consequently, numerous LMOFs have been isolated by using rigid aromatic carboxylate ligands. More recently, research on LMOFs constructed from flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands is now undergoing a period of rapid development in comparison to aromatic carboxylate LMOFs [12–20]. This is probably due to the versatile conformation of these kinds of flexible ligands which will endow the assembly system with structural diversity and more intriguing topologies as well as properties. Many reaction conditions also play important role in the self-assembly, among which tuning pH value of the solution is always a preferred method [21–26]. There are two major considerations. Firstly, the pH value frequently determines the deprotonation state of specific ligand which will affect the binding modes. Secondly, the generation of hydroxyl or oxo ligands is dependent on the pH value of the reaction. Recently, we have reported a series of LMOFs exhibiting strong fluorescent emissions based on flexible macrocyclic polyamine ligand which displays special coordination pattern and protonation scheme [27]. As part of our ongoing study of the analogous system, we have chosen 3,3′-tetramethyleneglutate (H2TMG) and 1,1′-cyclohexanediacetic acid (H2CHDC), as two flexible multifunctional organic linker to construct LMOFs. Previous studies of these ligands mainly focused on the development of transitional metal complexes [28–31]. Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and near-infrared luminescence property of two LMOFs, formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), which represents the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from one-dimensional (1D) chain to two-dimensional (2D) layer, revealing the pH effect on the supramolecular architecture.

Experimental SectionMaterials and General Methods

All commercially available reagents and starting materials were of reagent-grade quality and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were carried out on an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on PerkinElmer Spectrum One as KBr pellets in the range 4,000–400 cm−1. Solid-state luminescence spectrum in the near-infrared region was performed at room temperature on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer with a microsecond flash lamp (μF900, Edinburgh) as the excitation source (resolution 1.0 nm).

Synthesis of Complex [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]

A mixture of Sm3O2 (0.034 g, 0.10 mmol) and H2TMG (0.038 g, 0.20 mmol) in water solvent (8 mL) was adjusted to pH 2.0 with 1 mol/L HNO3, sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated at 160 °C for 72 h, then slowly cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Colorless needle-like crystals were recovered by filtration, washed by distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 52 % (based on H2TMG). Calcd for C18H27O9Sm(537.75): C 40.20, H 5.06, found: C 40.27, H 5.15. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445(m, br), 2936(s), 2867(m), 1707(m), 1597(s), 1582(s), 1567(vs), 1452(s), 1425(s), 1401(vs), 1218(m), 722(m), 693(m).

Synthesis of Complex [Nd<sub>2</sub>(CHDC)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]

A mixture of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.219 g, 0.50 mmol) and H2CHDC (0.080 g, 0.40 mmol) in water solvent (8 mL) was adjusted to pH 4.0 with 0.1 mol/L NaOH, sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated at 160 °C for 72 h, then slowly cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Purple prismatic crystals were recovered by filtration, washed by distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 47 % (based on H2CHDC). Calcd for C30H44O13Nd2(901.13): C 39.98, H 4.92, found: C 39.91, H 5.07. IR(KBr, cm−1): 3431(m, br), 2925(s), 2861(m), 1700(w), 1595(s), 1579(s), 1553(vs), 1455(s), 1441(s), 1403(vs), 1212(m), 725(m), 673(m).

X-Ray Crystallographic Study

Data collection was performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the CrystalClear program [32]. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 program [33]. All non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were generated geometrically (C–H bond fixed at 0.95 Å). Idealized positions of hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from Fourier difference maps and refined isotropically. Crystallographic data and structure determination summaries are listed in Table 1. Selected bond lengths for complex 1 and 2 are listed in Table 2.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structural of Compound <bold>1</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system and space group P-1. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographically independent Sm3+ centers, two complete deprotonated H2TMG, two partially deprotonated H2TMG and two water molecule. As illustrated in Fig. 1, both of the Sm1 and Sm2 ion is nine-coordinated by nine carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TMG2− and two HTMG− ligands in distorted tricapped triprismatic geometry. The Sm–O bond lengths vary from 2.367(3) to 2.583(3) Å. The Sm–O–Sm bond angles are in the range of 50.59(10)–152.96(11)°. Two crystallographically unique TMG2− in the asymmetric unit give the same coordination mode as depicted in Scheme 1a, each coordinating to three Sm3+ ions with hexadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode. Each of two HTMG− bonds to two Sm3+ ions using one carboxylate group while left the additional protonated carboxylate group uncoordinated (Scheme 1b), which has never been reported before [29–31]. On the basis of these connection modes of organic ligand, 1D infinite chain extending along the [100] direction is built up by the edge-sharing Sm3+ polyhedron, and the alternate intra-chain Sm···Sm distances is 3.856 and 4.101 Å (Fig. 2).

Crystal Structural of Compound <bold>2</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system and space group P2(1)/c. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographically independent Nd3+ centers, three complete deprotonated H2CHDC and one water molecule. As illustrated in Fig. 3, the Nd1 ion is nine-coordinated by nine carboxylate oxygen atoms from five CHDC2− ligands in distorted tricapped triprismatic geometry. The Nd2 ion is eight-coordinated, consisting of a water molecule and seven oxygen atoms from five CHDC2− ligands. The Nd–O bond lengths vary from 2.358(3) to 2.582(3) Å. The Nd–O–Nd bond angles are in the range of 50.86(11)–160.96(12)°. Three crystallographically unique CHDC2− ligands in the asymmetric unit exhibit three kinds of coordination modes as depicted in Scheme 1c–e. That is, one coordinates to four Nd3+ ions in tetradentate bridging mode, while the other two bond to three Nd3+ ions with hexadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode. On the basis of the later two kinds of connection modes of organic ligand, 1D infinite chain extending along the [100] direction is built up by the edge-sharing Nd3+ polyhedron, and the alternate intra-chain Nd···Nd distances is 4.048 and 4.010 Å (Fig. 4a–b). These chains are further cross-linked through the four-connected CHDC2− ligand, leading to the formation of the extended 2D layer structure, as illustrated in Fig. 4c.

Reaction Condition and Protonation Scheme of the Ligand

Compounds 1 and 2 were prepared under the same temperature and solvent, but different pH values of reaction mixture. It revealed that the low pH value of ca. 2.0 gave rise to partially deprotonated H2TMG in compound 1. It is noteworthy that the coordination mode as illustrated in Scheme 1b blocked the growth of the dimension of structure, finally giving 1D infinite chain. A high pH value of ca. 4.0 led to the separation of compound 2 with H2CHDC fully deprotonated, leading to the formation of the extended 2D layer structure. Further elevation of pH value in the reaction was failed because of the deposition of lanthanide ions at higher pH value. The structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligand and dimension of LMOFs.

Near-infrared Luminescence Property

Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of Nd(III) ions in the near-infrared region, the luminescence properties of complexes 2 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Under an excitation of 356 nm, complex 2 displays a strong emission band at 1065 nm (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), an emission band at 875 nm (4F3/2 → 4I9/2) with a much lower intensity, and a very weak band at 1329 nm (4F3/2 → 4I13/2) in the near-infrared region (Fig. 5). The profiles of the three characteristic bands and the relative intensity for complex 2 are consistent to the previously reported spectra of Nd(III) complexes [34, 35]. As described above, the structure was constructed from 1D inorganic chain. Thus the lanthanide ions are encapsulated in a rigid architecture, shielding them from interactions with the environment, especially from interactions with small molecules like water. Radiationless decay pathways associated with the close proximity of high-energy C–H, N–H, or O–H oscillators to the lanthanide centers can be eliminated. Efficient fluorescent emission for complex was then achieved.

Conclusions

In summary, two LMOFs with flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands, generally formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), have been successfully synthesized through the preheating and cooling-down crystallization approach. They represent the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from 1D infinite chains to 2D extended layer structure. Complexes 2 exhibit strong fluorescent emissions in the near-infrared region at room temperature. Interestingly, the structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligands and dimension of LMOFs. More efforts should be devoted to construct the predicted LMOFs through regulating the pH values. The related detailed study concerning this part is still underway in our group.

Supplementary Material

CCDC- 867652 (1) and 867653 (2) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. Copies of these data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

The Sm-O bond lengths vary from 2.367(3) to 2.583(3) Å. The Sm-O-Sm bond angles are in the range of 50.59(10)-152.96(11)°. Two crystallographically unique TMG2- in the asymmetric unit give the same coordination mode as depicted in Scheme 1a, each coordinating to three Sm3+ ions with hexadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode. Each of two HTMG- bonds to two Sm3+ ions using one carboxylate group while left the additional protonated carboxylate group uncoordinated (Scheme 1b), which has never been reported before [29-31]. On the basis of these connection modes of organic ligand, 1D infinite chain extending along the [100] direction is built up by the edge-sharing Sm3+ polyhedron, and the alternate intra-chain Sm⋅⋅⋅Sm distances is 3.856 and 4.101 Å (Fig. 2).Crystal Structural of Compound 2Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system and space group P2(1)/c. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographically independent Nd3+ centers, three complete deprotonated H2CHDC and one water molecule. As illustrated in Fig. 3, the Nd1 ion is nine-coordinated by nine carboxylate oxygen atoms from five CHDC2- ligands in distorted tricapped triprismatic geometry. The Nd2 ion is eight-coordinated, consisting of a water molecule and seven oxygen atoms from five CHDC2- ligands. The Nd-O bond lengths vary from 2.358(3) to 2.582(3) Å. The Nd-O-Nd bond angles are in the range of 50.86(11)-160.96(12)°. Three crystallographically unique CHDC2- ligands in the asymmetric unit exhibit three kinds of coordination modes as depicted in Scheme 1c-e. That is, one coordinates to four Nd3+ ions in tetradentate bridging mode, while the other two bond to three Nd3+ ions with hexadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode. On the basis of the later two kinds of connection modes of organic ligand, 1D infinite chain extending along the [100] direction is built up by the edge-sharing Nd3+ polyhedron, and the alternate intra-chain Nd⋅⋅⋅Nd distances is 4.048 and 4.010 Å (Fig. 4a-b). These chains are further cross-linked through the four-connected CHDC2- ligand, leading to the formation of the extended 2D layer structure, as illustrated in Fig. 4c.Reaction Condition and Protonation Scheme of the LigandCompounds 1 and 2 were prepared under the same temperature and solvent, but different pH values of reaction mixture. It revealed that the low pH value of ca. 2.0 gave rise to partially deprotonated H2TMG in compound 1. It is noteworthy that the coordination mode as illustrated in Scheme 1b blocked the growth of the dimension of structure, finally giving 1D infinite chain. A high pH value of ca. 4.0 led to the separation of compound 2 with H2CHDC fully deprotonated, leading to the formation of the extended 2D layer structure. Further elevation of pH value in the reaction was failed because of the deposition of lanthanide ions at higher pH value. The structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligand and dimension of LMOFs.Near-infrared Luminescence PropertyTaking into account the excellent luminescent properties of Nd(III) ions in the near-infrared region, the luminescence properties of complexes 2 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Under an excitation of 356 nm, complex 2 displays a strong emission band at 1065 nm (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), an emission band at 875 nm (4F3/2 → 4I9/2) with a much lower intensity, and a very weak band at 1329 nm (4F3/2 → 4I13/2) in the near-infrared region (Fig. 5). The profiles of the three characteristic bands and the relative intensity for complex 2 are consistent to the previously reported spectra of Nd(III) complexes [34, 35]. As described above, the structure was constructed from 1D inorganic chain. Thus the lanthanide ions are encapsulated in a rigid architecture, shielding them from interactions with the environment, especially from interactions with small molecules like water. Radiationless decay pathways associated with the close proximity of high-energy C-H, N-H, or O-H oscillators to the lanthanide centers can be eliminated. Efficient fluorescent emission for complex was then achieved.ConclusionsIn summary, two LMOFs with flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands, generally formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), have been successfully synthesized through the preheating and cooling-down crystallization approach. They represent the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from 1D infinite chains to 2D extended layer structure. Complexes 2 exhibit strong fluorescent emissions in the near-infrared region at room temperature. Interestingly, the structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligands and dimension of LMOFs. More efforts should be devoted to construct the predicted LMOFs through regulating the pH values. The related detailed study concerning this part is still underway in our group.Supplementary MaterialCCDC- 867652 (1) and 867653 (2) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two lanthanide-based metal-organic frameworks with flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands, generally formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), have been successfully synthesized and characterized. They represent the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from 1D infinite chains to 2D extended layer structure. Complexes 2 exhibit strong fluorescent emissions in the near-infrared region at room temperature. Interestingly, the structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligands and dimension of LMOFs.

elements.content: The current interest in the crystal engineering of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) stems not only from their potential application as functional materials, but also from their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies [1–4]. In order to design and synthesize novel MOFs with specific structures and properties, much effort has been focused on choosing the favored geometry and function of metal ions and organic ligands. Trivalent lanthanide ions, showing a wide range of technological applications, such as diagnostic tools, luminescent sensors and laser systems, has become important choice of functional metal ions in designing novel MOFs [5–8]. Besides, lanthanide-based MOFs (LMOFs) are expected to have intriguing structural features and charming topologies, owing to their higher coordination number and variable coordination geometry than transitional metals [9–11]. It is well-known that aromatic carboxylate ligands are excellent candidates to construct LMOFs with well-defined secondary building units and versatile architectures, and consequently, numerous LMOFs have been isolated by using rigid aromatic carboxylate ligands. More recently, research on LMOFs constructed from flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands is now undergoing a period of rapid development in comparison to aromatic carboxylate LMOFs [12–20]. This is probably due to the versatile conformation of these kinds of flexible ligands which will endow the assembly system with structural diversity and more intriguing topologies as well as properties. Many reaction conditions also play important role in the self-assembly, among which tuning pH value of the solution is always a preferred method [21–26]. There are two major considerations. Firstly, the pH value frequently determines the deprotonation state of specific ligand which will affect the binding modes. Secondly, the generation of hydroxyl or oxo ligands is dependent on the pH value of the reaction. Recently, we have reported a series of LMOFs exhibiting strong fluorescent emissions based on flexible macrocyclic polyamine ligand which displays special coordination pattern and protonation scheme [27]. As part of our ongoing study of the analogous system, we have chosen 3,3′-tetramethyleneglutate (H2TMG) and 1,1′-cyclohexanediacetic acid (H2CHDC), as two flexible multifunctional organic linker to construct LMOFs. Previous studies of these ligands mainly focused on the development of transitional metal complexes [28–31]. Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and near-infrared luminescence property of two LMOFs, formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), which represents the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from one-dimensional (1D) chain to two-dimensional (2D) layer, revealing the pH effect on the supramolecular architecture.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The current interest in the crystal engineering of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems not only from their potential application as functional materials, but also from their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies [1-4]. In order to design and synthesize novel MOFs with specific structures and properties, much effort has been focused on choosing the favored geometry and function of metal ions and organic ligands. Trivalent lanthanide ions, showing a wide range of technological applications, such as diagnostic tools, luminescent sensors and laser systems, has become important choice of functional metal ions in designing novel MOFs [5-8]. Besides, lanthanide-based MOFs (LMOFs) are expected to have intriguing structural features and charming topologies, owing to their higher coordination number and variable coordination geometry than transitional metals [9-11]. It is well-known that aromatic carboxylate ligands are excellent candidates to construct LMOFs with well-defined secondary building units and versatile architectures, and consequently, numerous LMOFs have been isolated by using rigid aromatic carboxylate ligands. More recently, research on LMOFs constructed from flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands is now undergoing a period of rapid development in comparison to aromatic carboxylate LMOFs [12-20]. This is probably due to the versatile conformation of these kinds of flexible ligands which will endow the assembly system with structural diversity and more intriguing topologies as well as properties. Many reaction conditions also play important role in the self-assembly, among which tuning pH value of the solution is always a preferred method [21-26]. There are two major considerations. Firstly, the pH value frequently determines the deprotonation state of specific ligand which will affect the binding modes. Secondly, the generation of hydroxyl or oxo ligands is dependent on the pH value of the reaction. Recently, we have reported a series of LMOFs exhibiting strong fluorescent emissions based on flexible macrocyclic polyamine ligand which displays special coordination pattern and protonation scheme [27]. As part of our ongoing study of the analogous system, we have chosen 3,3'-tetramethyleneglutate (H2TMG) and 1,1'-cyclohexanediacetic acid (H2CHDC), as two flexible multifunctional organic linker to construct LMOFs. Previous studies of these ligands mainly focused on the development of transitional metal complexes [28-31]. Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and near-infrared luminescence property of two LMOFs, formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), which represents the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from one-dimensional (1D) chain to two-dimensional (2D) layer, revealing the pH effect on the supramolecular architecture.

elements.content: All commercially available reagents and starting materials were of reagent-grade quality and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were carried out on an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on PerkinElmer Spectrum One as KBr pellets in the range 4,000–400 cm−1. Solid-state luminescence spectrum in the near-infrared region was performed at room temperature on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer with a microsecond flash lamp (μF900, Edinburgh) as the excitation source (resolution 1.0 nm).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All commercially available reagents and starting materials were of reagent-grade quality and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were carried out on an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on PerkinElmer Spectrum One as KBr pellets in the range 4,000-400 cm-1. Solid-state luminescence spectrum in the near-infrared region was performed at room temperature on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer with a microsecond flash lamp (μF900, Edinburgh) as the excitation source (resolution 1.0 nm).

elements.content: A mixture of Sm3O2 (0.034 g, 0.10 mmol) and H2TMG (0.038 g, 0.20 mmol) in water solvent (8 mL) was adjusted to pH 2.0 with 1 mol/L HNO3, sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated at 160 °C for 72 h, then slowly cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Colorless needle-like crystals were recovered by filtration, washed by distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 52 % (based on H2TMG). Calcd for C18H27O9Sm(537.75): C 40.20, H 5.06, found: C 40.27, H 5.15. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445(m, br), 2936(s), 2867(m), 1707(m), 1597(s), 1582(s), 1567(vs), 1452(s), 1425(s), 1401(vs), 1218(m), 722(m), 693(m).

Synthesis of Complex [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)]

A mixture of Sm3O2 (0.034 g, 0.10 mmol) and H2TMG (0.038 g, 0.20 mmol) in water solvent (8 mL) was adjusted to pH 2.0 with 1 mol/L HNO3, sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated at 160 °C for 72 h, then slowly cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Colorless needle-like crystals were recovered by filtration, washed by distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 52 % (based on H2TMG). Calcd for C18H27O9Sm(537.75): C 40.20, H 5.06, found: C 40.27, H 5.15. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3445(m, br), 2936(s), 2867(m), 1707(m), 1597(s), 1582(s), 1567(vs), 1452(s), 1425(s), 1401(vs), 1218(m), 722(m), 693(m).

elements.content: A mixture of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.219 g, 0.50 mmol) and H2CHDC (0.080 g, 0.40 mmol) in water solvent (8 mL) was adjusted to pH 4.0 with 0.1 mol/L NaOH, sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated at 160 °C for 72 h, then slowly cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Purple prismatic crystals were recovered by filtration, washed by distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 47 % (based on H2CHDC). Calcd for C30H44O13Nd2(901.13): C 39.98, H 4.92, found: C 39.91, H 5.07. IR(KBr, cm−1): 3431(m, br), 2925(s), 2861(m), 1700(w), 1595(s), 1579(s), 1553(vs), 1455(s), 1441(s), 1403(vs), 1212(m), 725(m), 673(m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complex [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)]

A mixture of Nd(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.219 g, 0.50 mmol) and H2CHDC (0.080 g, 0.40 mmol) in water solvent (8 mL) was adjusted to pH 4.0 with 0.1 mol/L NaOH, sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated at 160 °C for 72 h, then slowly cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Purple prismatic crystals were recovered by filtration, washed by distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 47 % (based on H2CHDC). Calcd for C30H44O13Nd2(901.13): C 39.98, H 4.92, found: C 39.91, H 5.07. IR(KBr, cm-1): 3431(m, br), 2925(s), 2861(m), 1700(w), 1595(s), 1579(s), 1553(vs), 1455(s), 1441(s), 1403(vs), 1212(m), 725(m), 673(m).

elements.content: Data collection was performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the CrystalClear program [32]. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 program [33]. All non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were generated geometrically (C–H bond fixed at 0.95 Å). Idealized positions of hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from Fourier difference maps and refined isotropically. Crystallographic data and structure determination summaries are listed in Table 1. Selected bond lengths for complex 1 and 2 are listed in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-Ray Crystallographic Study

Data collection was performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the CrystalClear program [32]. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 program [33]. All non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were generated geometrically (C-H bond fixed at 0.95 Å). Idealized positions of hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from Fourier difference maps and refined isotropically. Crystallographic data and structure determination summaries are listed in Table 1. Selected bond lengths for complex 1 and 2 are listed in Table 2.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system and space group P-1. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographically independent Sm3+ centers, two complete deprotonated H2TMG, two partially deprotonated H2TMG and two water molecule. As illustrated in Fig. 1, both of the Sm1 and Sm2 ion is nine-coordinated by nine carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TMG2− and two HTMG− ligands in distorted tricapped triprismatic geometry. The Sm–O bond lengths vary from 2.367(3) to 2.583(3) Å. The Sm–O–Sm bond angles are in the range of 50.59(10)–152.96(11)°. Two crystallographically unique TMG2− in the asymmetric unit give the same coordination mode as depicted in Scheme 1a, each coordinating to three Sm3+ ions with hexadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode. Each of two HTMG− bonds to two Sm3+ ions using one carboxylate group while left the additional protonated carboxylate group uncoordinated (Scheme 1b), which has never been reported before [29–31]. On the basis of these connection modes of organic ligand, 1D infinite chain extending along the [100] direction is built up by the edge-sharing Sm3+ polyhedron, and the alternate intra-chain Sm···Sm distances is 3.856 and 4.101 Å (Fig. 2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structural of Compound 1

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system and space group P-1. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographically independent Sm3+ centers, two complete deprotonated H2TMG, two partially deprotonated H2TMG and two water molecule. As illustrated in Fig. 1, both of the Sm1 and Sm2 ion is nine-coordinated by nine carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TMG2- and two HTMG- ligands in distorted tricapped triprismatic geometry. The Sm-O bond lengths vary from 2.367(3) to 2.583(3) Å. The Sm-O-Sm bond angles are in the range of 50.59(10)-152.96(11)°. Two crystallographically unique TMG2- in the asymmetric unit give the same coordination mode as depicted in Scheme 1a, each coordinating to three Sm3+ ions with hexadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode. Each of two HTMG- bonds to two Sm3+ ions using one carboxylate group while left the additional protonated carboxylate group uncoordinated (Scheme 1b), which has never been reported before [29-31]. On the basis of these connection modes of organic ligand, 1D infinite chain extending along the [100] direction is built up by the edge-sharing Sm3+ polyhedron, and the alternate intra-chain Sm⋅⋅⋅Sm distances is 3.856 and 4.101 Å (Fig. 2).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system and space group P2(1)/c. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographically independent Nd3+ centers, three complete deprotonated H2CHDC and one water molecule. As illustrated in Fig. 3, the Nd1 ion is nine-coordinated by nine carboxylate oxygen atoms from five CHDC2− ligands in distorted tricapped triprismatic geometry. The Nd2 ion is eight-coordinated, consisting of a water molecule and seven oxygen atoms from five CHDC2− ligands. The Nd–O bond lengths vary from 2.358(3) to 2.582(3) Å. The Nd–O–Nd bond angles are in the range of 50.86(11)–160.96(12)°. Three crystallographically unique CHDC2− ligands in the asymmetric unit exhibit three kinds of coordination modes as depicted in Scheme 1c–e. That is, one coordinates to four Nd3+ ions in tetradentate bridging mode, while the other two bond to three Nd3+ ions with hexadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode. On the basis of the later two kinds of connection modes of organic ligand, 1D infinite chain extending along the [100] direction is built up by the edge-sharing Nd3+ polyhedron, and the alternate intra-chain Nd···Nd distances is 4.048 and 4.010 Å (Fig. 4a–b). These chains are further cross-linked through the four-connected CHDC2− ligand, leading to the formation of the extended 2D layer structure, as illustrated in Fig. 4c.

Crystal Structural of Compound 2

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system and space group P2(1)/c. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographically independent Nd3+ centers, three complete deprotonated H2CHDC and one water molecule. As illustrated in Fig. 3, the Nd1 ion is nine-coordinated by nine carboxylate oxygen atoms from five CHDC2- ligands in distorted tricapped triprismatic geometry. The Nd2 ion is eight-coordinated, consisting of a water molecule and seven oxygen atoms from five CHDC2- ligands. The Nd-O bond lengths vary from 2.358(3) to 2.582(3) Å. The Nd-O-Nd bond angles are in the range of 50.86(11)-160.96(12)°. Three crystallographically unique CHDC2- ligands in the asymmetric unit exhibit three kinds of coordination modes as depicted in Scheme 1c-e. That is, one coordinates to four Nd3+ ions in tetradentate bridging mode, while the other two bond to three Nd3+ ions with hexadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode. On the basis of the later two kinds of connection modes of organic ligand, 1D infinite chain extending along the [100] direction is built up by the edge-sharing Nd3+ polyhedron, and the alternate intra-chain Nd⋅⋅⋅Nd distances is 4.048 and 4.010 Å (Fig. 4a-b). These chains are further cross-linked through the four-connected CHDC2- ligand, leading to the formation of the extended 2D layer structure, as illustrated in Fig. 4c.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 were prepared under the same temperature and solvent, but different pH values of reaction mixture. It revealed that the low pH value of ca. 2.0 gave rise to partially deprotonated H2TMG in compound 1. It is noteworthy that the coordination mode as illustrated in Scheme 1b blocked the growth of the dimension of structure, finally giving 1D infinite chain. A high pH value of ca. 4.0 led to the separation of compound 2 with H2CHDC fully deprotonated, leading to the formation of the extended 2D layer structure. Further elevation of pH value in the reaction was failed because of the deposition of lanthanide ions at higher pH value. The structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligand and dimension of LMOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Reaction Condition and Protonation Scheme of the Ligand

Compounds 1 and 2 were prepared under the same temperature and solvent, but different pH values of reaction mixture. It revealed that the low pH value of ca. 2.0 gave rise to partially deprotonated H2TMG in compound 1. It is noteworthy that the coordination mode as illustrated in Scheme 1b blocked the growth of the dimension of structure, finally giving 1D infinite chain. A high pH value of ca. 4.0 led to the separation of compound 2 with H2CHDC fully deprotonated, leading to the formation of the extended 2D layer structure. Further elevation of pH value in the reaction was failed because of the deposition of lanthanide ions at higher pH value. The structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligand and dimension of LMOFs.

elements.content: Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of Nd(III) ions in the near-infrared region, the luminescence properties of complexes 2 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Under an excitation of 356 nm, complex 2 displays a strong emission band at 1065 nm (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), an emission band at 875 nm (4F3/2 → 4I9/2) with a much lower intensity, and a very weak band at 1329 nm (4F3/2 → 4I13/2) in the near-infrared region (Fig. 5). The profiles of the three characteristic bands and the relative intensity for complex 2 are consistent to the previously reported spectra of Nd(III) complexes [34, 35]. As described above, the structure was constructed from 1D inorganic chain. Thus the lanthanide ions are encapsulated in a rigid architecture, shielding them from interactions with the environment, especially from interactions with small molecules like water. Radiationless decay pathways associated with the close proximity of high-energy C–H, N–H, or O–H oscillators to the lanthanide centers can be eliminated. Efficient fluorescent emission for complex was then achieved.
elements.clean_text:
Near-infrared Luminescence Property

Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of Nd(III) ions in the near-infrared region, the luminescence properties of complexes 2 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Under an excitation of 356 nm, complex 2 displays a strong emission band at 1065 nm (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), an emission band at 875 nm (4F3/2 → 4I9/2) with a much lower intensity, and a very weak band at 1329 nm (4F3/2 → 4I13/2) in the near-infrared region (Fig. 5). The profiles of the three characteristic bands and the relative intensity for complex 2 are consistent to the previously reported spectra of Nd(III) complexes [34, 35]. As described above, the structure was constructed from 1D inorganic chain. Thus the lanthanide ions are encapsulated in a rigid architecture, shielding them from interactions with the environment, especially from interactions with small molecules like water. Radiationless decay pathways associated with the close proximity of high-energy C-H, N-H, or O-H oscillators to the lanthanide centers can be eliminated. Efficient fluorescent emission for complex was then achieved.

elements.content: In summary, two LMOFs with flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands, generally formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), have been successfully synthesized through the preheating and cooling-down crystallization approach. They represent the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from 1D infinite chains to 2D extended layer structure. Complexes 2 exhibit strong fluorescent emissions in the near-infrared region at room temperature. Interestingly, the structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligands and dimension of LMOFs. More efforts should be devoted to construct the predicted LMOFs through regulating the pH values. The related detailed study concerning this part is still underway in our group.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two LMOFs with flexible alicyclic carboxylate ligands, generally formulated as [Sm(TMG)(HTMG)(H2O)] (1) and [Nd2(CHDC)3(H2O)] (2), have been successfully synthesized through the preheating and cooling-down crystallization approach. They represent the first example of lanthanide-TMG and lanthanide-CHDC systems. Their structures range from 1D infinite chains to 2D extended layer structure. Complexes 2 exhibit strong fluorescent emissions in the near-infrared region at room temperature. Interestingly, the structural difference between compounds 1 and 2 indicates the pH values have subtle influence on the coordination modes of ligands and dimension of LMOFs. More efforts should be devoted to construct the predicted LMOFs through regulating the pH values. The related detailed study concerning this part is still underway in our group.

A mixture of Sm3O2 (0.034 g, 0.10 mmol) and H2TMG (0.038 g, 0.20 mmol) in water solvent (8 mL) was adjusted to pH 2.0 with 1 mol/L HNO3, sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated at 160 °C for 72 h, then slowly cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Colorless needle-like crystals were recovered by filtration, washed by distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 52 % (based on H2TMG). Calcd for C18H27O9Sm(537.75): C 40.20, H 5.06, found: C 40.27, H 5.15. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445(m, br), 2936(s), 2867(m), 1707(m), 1597(s), 1582(s), 1567(vs), 1452(s), 1425(s), 1401(vs), 1218(m), 722(m), 693(m).

Synthesis of Complex [Nd<sub>2</sub>(CHDC)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]

A mixture of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.219 g, 0.50 mmol) and H2CHDC (0.080 g, 0.40 mmol) in water solvent (8 mL) was adjusted to pH 4.0 with 0.1 mol/L NaOH, sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated at 160 °C for 72 h, then slowly cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Purple prismatic crystals were recovered by filtration, washed by distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 47 % (based on H2CHDC). Calcd for C30H44O13Nd2(901.13): C 39.98, H 4.92, found: C 39.91, H 5.07. IR(KBr, cm−1): 3431(m, br), 2925(s), 2861(m), 1700(w), 1595(s), 1579(s), 1553(vs), 1455(s), 1441(s), 1403(vs), 1212(m), 725(m), 673(m).

metadata.title: Two Lanthanide-Based Metal–Organic Frameworks with Flexible Alicyclic Carboxylate Ligands: Synthesis, Crystal Structures, and Near-Infrared Luminescence Property
